docTitle.titlePart:
Anti-prothrombin IgG from patients with anti-phospholipid
antibodies inhibits the inactivation of factor Va by activated
protein C

front.div:
Thrombosis and obstetric complications occurring in patients
with anti-phospholipid antibodies define the anti-phospholipid
syndrome (Godfrey & D'Cruz, 2000). Over the last decade, it has
become clear that antiphospholipid antibodies are not directed
against phospholipids, but recognize lipid-bound plasma pro-
teins. The most common antigenic targets of anti-phospholipid
antibodies are b 2 -glycoprotein I (b 2 GPI) and prothrombin.
Anti-b 2 GPI antibodies are usually identified as 'anticardiolipin'
antibodies, because they react with cardiolipin in immunoas-
says, provided b 2 GPI is present (Galli et al, 1990; Matsuura
et al, 1990; McNeil et al, 1990). In subgroups of patients with
anti-b 2 GPI antibodies, anti-prothrombin antibodies or both,
lupus anticoagulant activity is found (Bevers et al, 1991; Galli
et al, 1992 and 1997; Oosting et al, 1992; Permpikul et al, 1994).
The protein C pathway causes a negative feedback of blood
coagulation through proteolytic inactivation of factor Va
(FVa) and factor VIIIa (FVIIIa); quantitative and/or qualitative
abnormalities of this pathway are associated with an increased
risk of venous thrombosis (Esmon, 2000). Since the late 1980s,
interference of anti-phospholipid antibodies with the antico-
agulant activity of this pathway has been investigated as one of
the possible causes of thrombosis in patients with the anti-
phospholipid syndrome. Anti-phospholipid antibodies have
been reported to inhibit both the activation of protein C
(Keeling et al, 1993; Toyoshima et al, 1993) and the activated
protein C (APC)-catalysed inactivation of FVa (Freyssinet &
Cazenave, 1987; Marciniak & Romond, 1989; Lo et al, 1990;
Malia et al, 1990; Borrell et al, 1992; Matsuda et al, 1995;
Smirnov et al, 1995; Galli et al, 1998; Ieko et al, 1999; Field
et al, 2000; Izumi et al, 2002; Nojima et al, 2002). In partic-
ular, plasmas or IgG fractions with lupus anticoagulant activity
exert this effect, which has been named 'acquired' resistance to
